Chapter 4, Part 4: Having explained ignorance, we will now explain name-and-form.
Form has already been extensively explained. What is the nature of name?
Verse:
Name is the four formless aggregates.
Commentary:
The Buddha said that the four formless aggregates are called name.
Why is it called name?
Because it can express and summon.
It means it can express and summon various objects.
If so, it should not completely include the formless and non-associated dharmas, because they have no objects.
No, the expression and summoning are only in the formless, just as there is no fault in explaining the name of form.

Moreover, because it is subtle, names are established according to principle in each meaning, and are designated with the name of expression, not without expression, etc. It can also be called name, because the basis of that can be obtained through direct perception.

Also, it is able to seek everywhere in all realms, stages, destinies, and births, and therefore it is established as name. It is not the case that the pure and formless realms cannot be called name. Although name is not what is being discussed here, it is similar to this.
Moreover, according to the feelings of those who speak of the formless realms, it is generally called name. There is no need to question this.
The extensive discernment of the rest is like the Correct Principles.
The characteristics of name have already been discussed.
What are the characteristics of contact?
Verse:
Contact arises from the union of the six [faculties], three [objects], and [consciousness].
Treatise:
There are six kinds of contact, namely eye contact up to mind contact.
What is this again?
It arises from the union of the three, namely the faculties, objects, and consciousness. Because of the union of the three, a separate contact arises.
Although the sixth [mind] and the three [objects] belong to different time periods, because cause and effect are related, the meaning of union is established.

Or the meaning of union is that they have the same effect. Although the faculties, objects, and consciousness may not necessarily arise together, because the effect of contact is the same, it is called union.
The substance of contact is a separate dharma, which has already been established among the ten universal activities.
Although it arises from the union of the three, it definitely occurs together with consciousness, because it is said to be born of two conditions like consciousness.
That is to say, a scripture says:
Internally there is the body of consciousness and externally there are name-and-form. The two pairs are conditions for the arising of various contacts, and so on at length.

The phrase internally there is the body of consciousness refers to the six internal sense bases, and the phrase externally there are name-and-form refers to the six external sense bases. This meaning is certain, because it is said in a verse.
As a verse says:
The two, eye and form, and so on.
Also, a scripture says:
Consciousness, contact, and name-and-form are conditions for each other.
Since the conditions for arising are the same, how can their times be different?
When the conditions are complete, they must arise, because there is nothing that can obstruct them.

On the basis of this, it is proven that such dharmas as feeling, which are born from contact through the union of the eye, etc., and consciousness, occur together with the consciousness of the eye, etc., because they are the same as the cause of the birth of the consciousness of the eye, etc.
On the basis of this, a scripture says:
This is feeling.ğŸ”½This is conceptualization.
This is volition.
This is consciousness.
Thus, these dharmas are mixed and inseparable, so the principle of consciousness and contact existing together is fully established.
These six kinds of contact are further combined into two.
What are the two?
The verse states:
The first five are associated with resistance, the sixth is both associated with resistance and has discursive thought.
The treatise states:
The first five contacts are called resistant because they take resistant faculties as their support and take only resistant dharmas as their objects.

The sixth contact of mind is called having discursive thought because discursive thought is name, and name is the extended object of mental contact, so it is unilaterally called contact with discursive thought.
Because mental consciousness generally takes names and meanings as its objects, while the first five do not take names as objects, it is said to be extended.
It is said that eye consciousness only cognizes blue but does not cognize it is blue, while mental consciousness cognizes blue and also cognizes it is blue, and so on at length.
Therefore, the name resistant contact comes from the support and object, while the name contact with discursive thought is established based on the extended object.
Some say that mental consciousness is called â€œhaving conceptual proliferationâ€ because it is dominant in the production of speech.

Some say that mental consciousness is called â€œhaving conceptual proliferationâ€ because it turns toward an object only when it is dominant in speech, but the five consciousnesses are not like this. Therefore mental consciousness alone is called â€œhaving conceptual proliferation,â€ and that which is associated with it is called â€œcontact having conceptual proliferation.â€

Therefore contact associated with resistance is named according to its support and object, while contact having conceptual proliferation is named according to its association with the dominant factor.
The six kinds of contact are divided into eight kinds according to their specific associations.
A verse says:
Light, darkness, and neither, pure, defiled, and the rest,
Associated with craving and hatred, and with pleasure, etc., in accordance with the three feelings.
The treatise says:

Contact associated with light, darkness, etc., is threefold: contact associated with light, contact associated with darkness, and contact associated with neither light nor darkness. These three should be understood as pure, defiled, and the rest of contact associated with them.
The rest refers to the pure and the rest of the defiled, that is, contaminated good and nondefiled and non-defined.
A part of the defiled contact occurs frequently, and on the basis of that, the two contacts of love and hatred are established, because the propensities of love and hatred are associated with it.

When all are combined, they form three contacts: contact that is conducive to a pleasant feeling, contact that is conducive to a painful feeling, and contact that is conducive to a neither painful nor pleasant feeling.
What is contact that is conducive to a pleasant feeling?
Because it is experienced by pleasant feeling, etc.
Or it is called conducive to feeling because it is the support for the mode of activity of feeling.
How is contact the support for the mode of activity of feeling?
Because the mode of activity is extremely similar to contact, and it is born in dependence on contact.
Also, because it is associated with pleasant feeling, etc., or because it is able to attract pleasant feeling, etc., it is called conducive to feeling.
Thus they combine to form sixteen kinds of contact.
The characteristics of contact have been discussed.
What are the characteristics of feeling?
A verse says:
From this, six feelings arise. Five belong to the body and the rest to the mind.
These are further divided into eighteen, due to differences in mental activities.
The treatise states:
From the previous six contacts, six feelings are produced, namely, feeling born of contact with the eye up to feeling born of contact with the mind.
These combine to form two, namely, bodily feeling and mental feeling.
Of the six, the first five are called bodily feeling because they are based on material organs.
That born of contact with the mind is called mental feeling because it is based on the mind alone.
Within the previously mentioned single mental feeling, it is divided into eighteen on the basis of differences in the activities of the mind.
What are the eighteen activities of the mind?
They are the six activities of sorrow, joy, and indifference.
Why are they established as eighteen?
Because the three feelings are associated only with mind and there are differences in the six objects, they are made into eighteen.
It is not that a single feeling is associated with mental consciousness and becomes six because of differences in objects, because of differences in the feelings.
What is the meaning of the term activities of the mind ?
Joy, etc., have the power to act as proximate conditions and make the mind frequently travel to objects.

If you say that joy, etc., are called mental activities because they are the proximate conditions of mind, then conceptualization, etc., should also be called mental activities, because they are associated with mind and are mental activities by means of mind.
If mental activities are only of the realm of manas, then are you not contradicting the scriptures?
A scripture says,
When the eye sees material forms, one produces the mental activity of joy with regard to desirable forms.
This is not a contradiction, just as the contemplation of impurity is categorized as the realm of manas, even though it is aroused by visual consciousness.
A scripture says,
When the eye sees material forms, one contemplates impurity and abides in it.
This is also like that. The mental activities of joy, etc., are aroused by the five consciousnesses and are of the realm of manas. Therefore the scripture says,
When the eye sees material forms, etc.
Therefore mental activities are aroused by the five consciousnesses and are associated with the manas consciousness. This should not be a problem.
Why are bodily feelings not mental activities?
because they are not of the same substance as the mind.
Because the activities of the mind are based only on mental consciousness, they are called near.
Because they discriminate the specific and common characteristics of objects of the three times, etc., they are called activities.
All bodily feelings are the opposite of this, and therefore they are not near to the mind, nor are they called activities.
Arenâ€™t bodily feelings also like this?
After bodily feelings have received visible forms, etc., mental consciousness follows and acts, because mental consciousness repeatedly acts on objects by the power of bodily feelings.
This is also not so, because the characteristics have already been explained, that is, because bodily feelings are not based on mental consciousness, because they are nondiscriminative.
Because they are unable to discriminate the virtues and faults of objects, they do not cause mental consciousness to act repeatedly on objects.

Also, because they are not fixed, that is, because bodily feelings are not definitely followed by the arising of mental consciousness, and because mental feelings must be accompanied by mental consciousness. Therefore only mental feelings are called activities of the mind.
Also, even though the blind and so on do not see, etc., and do not touch, they still have mental activities.
Also, the mental pleasure of the third trance state should be included in the mental activities.
This objection is not reasonable, because the first realm does not have it.
Also, because it is stagnant. That is, in the realm of desire there is no mental pleasure. Although the third trance state has it, it is not established.

Also, the pleasure of that stage is stagnant with regard to its object. Mental activities with regard to objects often have movement and change, and are not stagnant with one object. This is called activity.
Also, because there is no mental activity that is associated with the faculty of suffering.
In that case, there should be no mental activity of indifference, because there is nothing with which it is associated.
This is not so, because sorrow and joy are associated with indifference.
The faculty of pleasure of the third trance state does not have the faculty of indifference of its own fundamental stage with which it is associated.

However, there is no error in saying that there is no preliminary stage, etc., and no indifference, etc., mental activities, because in the first realm there is that with which it is associated in the same stage.

Or, it is possible to have, and not possible to have, because it is possible for the mind and indifference, etc., to have the same realm as the opposing dharmas, but the mind and joy definitely do not have the same realm as the opposing dharmas, therefore there is no error.
How many of the various mental activities are bound to the desire realm?
How many of the mental activities of the desire realm take what as their objects?
The same question is asked of the form and formless realms.
The verse says:
The desire realm has eighteen [mental activities] that take the desire realm as their objects. The form realm has twelve. The upper two [realms] have three.
Two [realms] have twelve that take the desire realm as their objects. Eight are of the same realm. Two are of the formless realm.
The last two [realms] have six that take the desire realm as their objects. Four are of the same realm. One takes the upper realm as its object.
The preliminary stage of the first formless realm has four that take form as their objects. One is of the same realm.
The four fundamental [formless realms] and three adjacent [formless realms] have only one that takes its own objects as its objects.
The treatise says:
Those bound to the desire realm have all eighteen [mental activities]. Those that take the desire realm as their objects are also that many in number.
Those that take the form realm as their objects only have twelve, excluding the six of smell and taste, because they do not have those objects.
When taking the formless realm as object, there are only three, because there are no five objects such as form there.
When taking the unconditioned as object, there are also only three.
Having explained those belonging to the desire realm, we will now explain those belonging to the form realm.
The first two meditations have only twelve, excluding the six of sorrow. If it is said that there is no defilement in the meditations, then it is able to take lower realms as objects.
The good takes the desire realm as object and also has twelve, excluding the four of smell and taste, and the remaining eight take themselves as objects.
The two take the formless realm as object, namely the mental activities of dharmas.
Taking the unconditioned as object also has only two kinds.
The third and fourth meditations have only six, namely equanimity taking the desire realm as object.
The good also has six, excluding the two of smell and taste, and the remaining four take themselves as objects.
One takes the formless realm as object, namely the mental activities of dharmas.
Taking the unconditioned as object also has only one kind.
Having explained those belonging to the form realm, we will now explain those belonging to the formless realm.
The preliminary stage of the sphere of infinite space has only four kinds, namely equanimity taking form, sound, touch, and dharmas as objects.
The fourth meditative absorption also has four kinds, this is said with reference to those who admit that it has separate objects.
If one holds that this level only generally takes the lower levels as objects, then there is only the mental application of taking mixed objects.
Taking the formless realm as object is only one kind, namely, the mental application of taking the dharma as object.
Taking the unconditioned as object is also only one kind.

The four fundamental stages and the three upper stages have only one kind, namely, the mental application of taking the dharma as object. It also takes its own stage as object, because the fundamental formless realm does not take the lower stages as objects, and because the three upper stages do not take form as objects.
The meaning of not taking the lower stages will be explained later.
Taking the unconditioned as object is also only one kind.
Are all mental applications both with and without impurities?
The verse states:
The eighteen only have impurities.
The treatise states:
There are no mental applications that are both with and without impurities.
Why is this?
Because they increase existence.
The dharmas without impurities are contrary to this.
Some say that mental applications exist for all sentient beings, but those without impurities do not, therefore they are not mental applications.

Some say: The noble path proceeds spontaneously, and therefore it is in conformity with the formless realm. Therefore it is not the substance of the mental activities. Because the substance of the mental activities is contrary to this.
Who possesses how many mental activities?

If one is born in the realm of desire and has not yet acquired a good mind of the realm of form, one possesses all of the first two meditations, eight of the third and fourth meditations, and one of the formless realm.
Those that are accomplished in the upper realms all have no objects in the lower realms, because they are only defiled.
If one has already acquired a good mind of the realm of form but has not yet eliminated the craving of the realm of desire, one possesses all of the realm of desire and ten of the first meditation.
The four of equanimity have six kinds, because the good mind of the stage of the preliminary meditation can have as its object the objects of smell and taste.
The four of joy only have four kinds, because they are only defiled and do not have as their objects the lower realms.
Are the mental activities not attracted by the consciousnesses of the eye, etc.?
Since they do not have the two consciousnesses of the nose and tongue, they should not have mental activities with smell and taste as objects.

This criticism is unreasonable, because the self-nature of the blind and deaf, etc., would not have any recollection, and in samÄdhi there would be no bodily and mental activities. Therefore not all are attracted by the five consciousnesses.
The two samÄdhis are accomplished in eight, and the third and fourth dhyÄnas and formless [attainments] are as before.
If one has already separated from craving but has not yet attained the wholesome mind of the two samÄdhis, one accomplishes twelve in the desire realm and first dhyÄna, excluding the six of sorrow.
The second dhyÄna, etc., are all as explained before.

If one has already attained the wholesome mind of the two samÄdhis, but has not yet attained separation from craving in the first dhyÄna, one accomplishes ten in the two samÄdhis, namely, joy is only four, because it is only defiled;
abandonment has six kinds, because one has already attained the wholesome of its threshold.
The rest are as explained before. By this principle, the rest should be understood accordingly.

If one is born in the form realm, one only accomplishes one abandonment dharma bodily and mental activity in the desire realm, namely, that associated with the mind of the fruit of the unimpeded path.
How does one attain the various mental activities?

That is, when one is free from attachment to desire realm objects, in the first eight uninterrupted paths and eight liberated paths, one obtains six types of equanimity associated with the stage of the preliminary concentration of the first meditation. In the ninth uninterrupted path and liberated path, one obtains the equanimity associated with the mind of the fruit of supernormal knowledge belonging to the desire realm.
When one obtains the first meditation, one obtains twelve types of equanimity. The term first meditation here includes its retinue.
By this principle, one should understand as appropriate when one is free from attachment to the upper stages.

However, there is a difference. When one is free from attachment to the desire for the fourth meditation, the ninth uninterrupted path and liberated path definitely do not obtain the equanimity associated with the mind of the fruit of supernormal knowledge belonging to the lower stages.

When one is free from attachment to the stages such as the sphere of infinite space, in all the uninterrupted paths and liberated paths, one only obtains one type of equanimity associated with dharmas.

When one obtains the stage of no more learning, one obtains twelve types of equanimity belonging to the desire realm and the first two meditations, and six types of equanimity belonging to the third and fourth meditations.
Four types of equanimity belonging to the sphere of infinite space.
Each of the higher stages has one dharma, namely equanimity.

When one is born in a stage, when one falls from a higher stage and is born in a lower stage, one acquires the various forms of equanimity of the stage where one is born. When one is born in the formless realms, one acquires the dharma of equanimity of the lower stage. These are the eighteen forms of mental activity of joy, etc.

Because they are the basis of indulgence and the basis of emergence, the World Honored One has said that they are the thirty-six teachersâ€™ phrases. These phrases of distinction are able to reveal the Great Teacher, and are therefore called the teachersâ€™ phrases.
Only the Buddha, the Great Teacher, is able to know and speak of these phrases. Others are not able to.
The basis of indulgence refers to defiled feelings.
The basis of emergence refers to the good and nondetermined feelings, because they accord with the good and the defiled.
They are included in the two categories as appropriate, and are not separately discussed.
As for the definite number of these thirty-six in the realms and stages, it means that in the realm of desire there are all thirty-six.
In the first two meditations there are only twenty, that is, eight based on indulgence and twelve based on emergence.
The fourth and third dhyÄnas have only ten kinds, that is, four based on enjoyment and six based on leaving.
If the preliminary concentration of the sphere of infinite space is allowed to have a separate object, then it has five kinds, that is, one based on enjoyment and four based on leaving.
If it is held that it only has a general object, then it has only two kinds, that is, one based on enjoyment and one based on leaving.
The formless realms and the three edges above each have only two, which should be understood as before.
As for the distinctions of realms and stages and objects of concentration, desire is related to objects of desire and has thirty-six.
It is related to objects of the form realm and has only twenty-four, excluding the two based on smell and taste, each of which is six.
It is related to objects of the formless realm and has only six kinds, that is, the three based on the application of dharmas.
It is related to objects of the unconditioned realm and also has only these six.
By this principle, the distinctions of objects related to the form and formless realms should be considered as appropriate.
Why is it that the remaining members are not discussed?
The verse states:
The rest have already been discussed or will be discussed.
The treatise states:
The remaining members have either been explained or will be explained, as has been previously distinguished.
If this is so, then why is this verse raised again?
It is in order to refute the extensive explanation in the following verse.
Because in the following verse it speaks of afflictions, etc., one should not give rise to such doubts.
The meaning of the four members has already been extensively clarified above, and next one should extensively explain the remaining members.

In order to show that the following text relies on afflictions, karma, and events, it metaphorically illustrates the twelve members of dependent arising in a general way, and therefore the preceptors raise this verse again.
As has been said above, the twelve members of dependent arising are summarized as only three: afflictions, karma, and events. These three have different functions.
What are their metaphors?
A verse says:
Here, afflictions are said to be like seeds and also like dragons,ğŸ”½Like grass roots, tree trunks, and like rice covered with chaff;
Karma is like rice with chaff, like medicinal grass, and like flowers;
The various karmic retribution events are like cooked and ready-to-eat food.
The treatise says:
How are these three similar to each other, like sprouts, leaves, etc. arising from seeds?
Thus, afflictions give rise to afflictions, karma, and events, like a dragon presiding over a pond, the water never drying up.
Thus, afflictions obtaining continuity preside over the pond of birth, causing the flow of afflictions, karma, and events to be inexhaustible.

Like grass whose roots have not been pulled out, the sprouts are cut but grow again. Thus, the roots of afflictions have not been pulled out by the noble path, causing the sprouts of birth to be cut but to arise again and again.
Like branches, flowers, and fruits frequently arising from a tree trunk, thus afflictions repeatedly give rise to afflictions, karma, and events.
Like rice wrapped in husks is able to produce sprouts, etc., but alone is unable to produce, karma wrapped in afflictions is able to attract future existence, but alone is unable to attract.
Like rice with husks is able to produce sprouts, etc., karma with afflictions is able to attract karmic retribution.
Just as when plants and herbs bear fruit, they are finished, and when the fruit of karma is mature, it does not again produce a retribution.
Just as a flower is the proximate cause of a fruit, so karma is the proximate cause that produces retribution.

Just as cooked food is only to be enjoyed and cannot be transformed into other food, so when the matter of the retribution fruit is already mature, it cannot again attract another birth of retribution.
If the retribution again attracts another birth, and that again attracts another, there would be no liberation.

Having explained dependent origination, within this, it is divided into four kinds of existence based on stages, with intermediate existence, birth existence, prior existence, and death existence as previously explained.
The distinctions of good, etc., and whether they exist in the three realms will now be briefly discussed.
A verse says:
Among the four kinds of existence, birth existence is only defiled,
Due to the afflictions of one's own stage. The other three are without form and three in the formless realm.
The treatise says:
Among the four kinds of existence, birth existence is only defiled, definitely not good or non-obscured-non-defined.
By what passions are all the passions, the defilements of the passions, and the defilements of birth and existence produced?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
They are only produced by the passions of oneâ€™s own stage.
That is, one born in a certain stage is only defiled by the passions of that stage.
There is not a single passion that lacks the power to moisten and unite with birth. However, the union with birth is only due to the power of the passions, not to the bonds and secondary passions.
Why is this?
Because remorse, concealment, and other bonds and secondary passions must be produced through reflection.
However, in this state, body and mind are dull and weak, and only the spontaneous passions can be active.
Only the propensities, which are powerful through repeated practice, can be active many times as passions. At the time of uniting with birth, they are spontaneously active.

The bonds and secondary passions are weak in the power of repeated practice, and they cannot be active without reflection. Therefore, uniting with birth is not due to the bonds and secondary passions.
Therefore, the power of the afflictions of the same stage alone can defile the birth existence. This principle is completely established.
The other intermediate existences, etc., are all of three kinds, that is, they are all wholesome, defiled, and indeterminate.
You should understand that the first moment of the intermediate existence that is produced is also necessarily defiled, just as is the case with the birth existence.
To what realms are these four existences connected?
The three realms are connected to all four. The formless realm is connected to only three, because intermediate existence is not the result of formless realm karma.
This has been fully investigated in the Saá¹ƒyuktÃ¢bhidharmahá¹›daya.
By what do sentient beings abide in these four kinds of existences?
Verse:
Sentient beings abide by means of food. The substance of the three foods in the desire realm is only three.
Formless cannot benefit itself, because it is liberated from the faculties.
The three foods of contact, intention, and consciousness are contaminated and extend to the three realms.
The intermediate existence that seeks birth is produced by smelling fragrance.
The first two benefit this world, the support and what is supported.
The latter two, in order, attract and produce future existence.
The treatise says:
The sutras say that the World Honored One himself realized and correctly awakened to and correctly taught one dharma, namely that all sentient beings without exception dwell by means of food.
What are the foods?
There are four kinds of foods:
1. coarse, 2. contact, 3. intention, and 4. consciousness.
Coarse food is of two kinds: subtle and coarse.
Subtle refers to the food of the intermediate existence, because it takes smell as food;
and to the food of the gods at the beginning of the eon, because it is free from impurity.
Like sand soaked in oil, it enters the limbs. Therefore it is said to be subtle. Food that is the opposite of this is called coarse.
Such coarse food exists only in the desire realm, because one is born in the upper realms free from craving for coarse food.

The body of the upper realms does not depend on external conditions for sustenance, and although the form realm has great elements that can benefit, they are not coarse food, like non-excellent desires.
Although there are subtle forms, sounds, and tangibles in the form realm, they do not generate excessive craving, so they are not called subtle desires.
In the same way, although there is the most excellent and subtle contact that benefits, it is ultimately without the division and swallowing of morsels, so it is not a morsel of food.
Although it is not categorized as a morsel of food, it is not without the meaning of food.
Just as joy, although not categorized among the four foods, is said in the scriptures to be food, because it has the meaning of food.
As a scripture says:
I eat the food of joy.
Because of the food of joy, I remain for a long time, like the gods of Abhasvara Heaven.
However, the substance of morsel food consists of thirteen things, but in general it is only of three kinds, namely, only the three of smell, taste, and touch in the desire realm.
All of them are the substance of morsel food, because they can be divided into morsels and swallowed.
This is said because the mouth and nose receive them in parts, and the few are taken from the many.
Although it is not swallowed, it can still benefit the body and allow it to remain for a long time. It is also categorized as fine food, just like shadows, light, flames, and cool ointments.
Moreover, in the initial stage of the eon, food such as earth essence is also called coarse food, because it is received in portions.
Moreover, all drinks are also called coarse food, because they can all be received and used in separate portions.
The form realm is called coarse, but it is not called food, because it cannot nourish and benefit the faculties that confront it.
As for the term food, it nourishes the faculties and the great elements.
The form realm has no power to nourish and benefit its own faculties and the great elements, because it is the object of the faculties that do not reach it.

A scripture says: Coarse food cannot perform its function of nourishing when it is in the hand or in a vessel. It must enter the nose and mouth, be chewed by the teeth, soaked by saliva, pass through the throat, fall into the stomach, gradually be digested, and the essence of its flavor and maturity flow into the blood vessels, nourishing the various worms, only then is it called food, because only then can it perform the function of nourishing.

If it is in the hand or a vessel, it is named after that, like Devadatta or hell. Although the parts of food in general are called food, when they become food, they are only smell, taste, and touch, because at that time only these are the objects of the sense faculties.
Also, how do you know that the form element is not food?

Because the internal inclusion and benefit of the sense faculties and the great elements are seen separately, like smell, taste, and touch. At that time, the consciousness of those objects is not produced.

Even when producing one's own consciousness, it still does not harm or benefit one's own sense faculties and the great elements, let alone entering the body and not producing one's own consciousness, it can serve as food.
Seeing the sun and moon disks, etc., can harm or benefit the eye faculty. This is the function of touch, not the power of form and appearance.
Isn't it that pleasure and pain arise together with consciousness, and these two can serve as harm and benefit? Therefore, the form element also harms and benefits the eye.

This is not reasonable, because the eye and light, etc., should become food. However, serving as objects that accord with painful or pleasant touch can serve as food, but the form element does not do this.

When one sees the various colors of a plate, chopsticks, and food, the eye is not benefited or harmed. Only when they reach the eye does the eye benefit or harm. Therefore, material food definitely is not the form realm.
If this is so, why is material food praised in the scriptures as possessing form, smell, and taste?
In order to bring delight, it is praised as an auxiliary condition. It is like praising respectfully giving. How could respect be called material food?

However, material food possesses both the primary and auxiliary conditions. Moreover, the form aspect is mentioned to indicate that smell, taste, and touch are also wonderful and delightful. Therefore, it is said this way.
Therefore, the substance of food is only smell, taste, and touch. Form cannot benefit one's own faculties and liberation.
The so-called food must first benefit one's own faculties and the primary elements, and then it can reach the others.
When one sees form, it does not benefit one's own faculties and primary elements, let alone being able to reach the others. This is because the objects of the various faculties are different.
Sometimes when one sees form and gives rise to joy and pleasure, the food is the contact that arises from form, not form itself.
Also, nonreturners and arhats who are liberated from craving for food do not experience joy when they see delicious food, because it is of no benefit to them.
The realms to which the three foods of contact, intention, and consciousness belong have been discussed. Now we will show their essential natures.
Contact is that which is born from the union of the three: faculty, object, and consciousness. It has been extensively investigated in the chapter on mental activities.
Intention is mental action. Consciousness is that which perceives objects.
These three are only impure and are found in all three realms.
Thus the four foods have a total of sixteen substances. Only the last three foods are said to be impure, to show that the three of odor, etc., are not confused with the pure.
Why are pure contact, etc., not foods?
Food is that which attracts and nourishes existence, which is detestable and to be abandoned, and which is the place where craving grows.

Although the pure nourish the existence attracted by others, they do not have the power to attract existence themselves, and they are not the place where detestable and abandoned craving grows, and therefore they are not established as being in the four foods.
For this reason, even though impure dharmas of other realms and stages are causes, they are not nutriment.
Even though dharmas of other realms and stages are causes that nourish the present, they are not able to act as causes that attract subsequent existence. Therefore they are not called nutriments.
When pure dharmas are present, even though they are causes that nourish the fundamental material elements, they are not able to act as causes that attract subsequent existence.

Even though they are causes that temporarily nourish the fundamental material elements, they are only able to form a superior support for the desire to quickly enter nirvÄá¹‡a and eternally destroy existence.
When impure dharmas of the same stage are present, they nourish the present and increase it and are able to attract subsequent existence.

Thus the meaning of the statement that material food is a cause of subsequent existence is that when contact, etc., attract subsequent existence, they also attract future internal odors, etc. Present internal odors, etc., nourish the causes of contact, etc., causing them to attract future existence, and they are also able to attract future odors, etc., as results of similar activity. Therefore material food, as a cause of subsequent existence, is also able to attract existence because it has the same effect.
However, odors, flavors, and tangible objects are of three kinds: born of retribution, as results of similar activity, and as nourishment.
Because external odors, etc., arouse internal odors, flavors, and tangible objects in the body and cause them to become nourishment, the theory of nourishment is definitely established.
A scripture says, The four kinds of nourishment cause sentient beings who already exist to abide and support those seeking birth.
The term beings who already exist indicates that they have already been born.
All those who have been born in the various destinies are called beings who already exist.
What does the term those seeking birth refer to?
The Buddha has said that the intermediate existence has five names.
What are the five?
1. It is called manas, because it is born from manas, that is, it is the result of the projecting karma.
If this is so, then it would be too broad a definition.
No, because the intermediate existence does not take up external conditions such as semen and blood to form its body.
2. It is called seeking birth, because it is often delighted to investigate the place of its future birth.
Birth means birth existence. In the intermediate state, there is much seeking to go to the place of birth existence.
3. It is called eating smells, because it goes to the place of birth by eating smells as food for the body.
4. It is called intermediate existence, because there is no interruption between death and birth.
5. It is called arising, because the body suddenly arises without interruption between death and birth.
Or it is said to be directed toward the future birth, because it arises temporarily.
Why is it said that there are only four kinds of food?
All conditioned things have the function of food, because the scriptures say that nirvÄá¹‡a also has food.
A scripture says:
NirvÄá¹‡a has nutriment, namely the limbs of enlightenment.
Although all conditioned dharmas are nutriment, it is said in a general way that there are four nutriments.

The Great Sage, for the sake of those to be liberated, spoke of only four nutriments, because the first two nutriments benefit the body, which is the support, and that which is supported, while the last two nutriments attract future existence and produce future existence.
The four nutriments are established because they benefit and attract the two kinds of existence of name-and-form.
The support refers to form, which is the body with organs.
That which is supported refers to name, which is mind and mental factors.
Among them, material food benefits the support, because the body with organs exists because of it.
Among them, contact food benefits that which is supported, because mind and mental factors are sustained by it.
These two kinds of nutriment have the most excellent power to benefit the existence that has already arisen.
Volition is the projecting cause, and consciousness is the seed that projects future existence, that is, by reason of action, name-and-form in a future existence is projected.
When action has projected, thirst moistens the seed of consciousness and causes the name-and-form body of future existence to arise.
Therefore a scripture says,
Action is the cause of birth, and thirst is the cause of arising.
These two nutriments are most excellent in projecting power with regard to future existence that has not yet arisen. Therefore only these four are called nutriments.
Of these four nutriments, the last two are like a mother who gives birth, because they give birth to that which has not yet arisen.
The first two are like a foster mother, because they nourish that which has already arisen.
The extensive discernment of these four nutriments is as explained in the Abhidharmasamuccaya.
We must now consider the four kinds of existence as explained above. The two existences of death and birth are only one moment in duration. What kind of consciousness appears at this moment?
Also, with what kind of feeling is this consciousness associated?
Can one die and be reborn in a state of samÄdhi or in a mindless state?
In what kind of consciousness does one enter nirvÄá¹‡a?
At the time of death, where does consciousness cease?
What is the substance of the severed life-sustaining nÄá¸Ä«?
Verse:
Severing the roots of goodness and reconnecting them, being free from defilements, regressing, dying, and being reborn,
It is only admitted to be in the mental consciousness. Dying and being reborn are only in the feeling of equanimity.
Not in the two meditative absorptions, nor in the two mindless states, nor in nirvÄá¹‡a.
Gradually dying, at the feet, navel, and heart, the last moment of mental consciousness ceases.
Below humans and celestials, there is no rebirth. The severed life-sustaining nÄá¸Ä« is water and so forth.
The treatise says:

In the six states of severing the roots of goodness, reconnecting the roots of goodness, being free from the defilements of the realms and stages, regressing from being free from the defilements, dying, and being reborn, it is only admitted to be the mental consciousness, because these are all unique dharmas of the mental consciousness. The five consciousnesses have no function in these.
The word being reborn also includes the first moment of the intermediate state.

Although mental consciousness is associated with three feelings, at death and birth there is only the feeling of indifference, not the feelings of pleasure or pain, because the natures of pleasure and pain are extremely clear and sharp and do not accord with death and birth.
There is no death and birth in a consciousness that is not clear and sharp, because death and birth must be dull and weak.

Consequently, it is said that in the three lower trance states, there is death and birth only in the access concentration, because the fundamental trance states do not have the feeling of indifference.

Even though it is said that death and birth occur in mental consciousness, they do not occur in the mind in samÄdhi, because there is no death and birth in a different realm or spiritual stage.ğŸ”½Even if there is no difference in realm or spiritual stage, death and birth do not occur because the mind in samÄdhi is extremely clear and sharp, because it is attracted and generated by superior added effort,ğŸ”½and because the mind in samÄdhi benefits, and death occurs only through harm.
Death and birth do not occur in the mind in samÄdhi because it is not defiled, and one receives life only through a defiled mind.
Also, because a defiled mind of a different stage benefits the body, there is no death. Because it is generated by preparatory effort, there is no rebirth.
A defiled mind of a different stage is necessarily categorized as a superior stage, and it is impossible to enjoy going to an inferior stage to be reborn.

A neutral mind of a different stage is not defiled and is generated by preparatory effort, and therefore there is no death or rebirth, and it is also not mindless. The reason is that the meaning of death and rebirth is contradictory.
There are two kinds of death: death caused by the agency of another or natural death.
In a state of unconsciousness, one cannot be killed by another, because a special dharma sustains the body.
In a state of unconsciousness, one does not naturally die, because one can be drawn out of samÄdhi by a mind of the same species.

That is, the mind of samÄdhi acts as an equal and immediate condition and seizes the dharmas of body and mind that are supported by it. Certainly there is no other dharma that can obstruct and prevent their arising.
If the supported body is about to perish, it must generate again the body and mind of this stage, and only then can death occur. There is no other way.
There is also a sutra that proves that one does not die without mind. A sutra says:

When sentient beings in the state of non-perception arise from that state, they die from that place. One cannot be reborn in a state without mind, because one must be reborn by the power of the present mind. Because one is reborn in a state of dullness and inferiority. Because one cannot be reborn without arousing afflictions.
There is also a sutra that proves that one is not reborn without mind. A sutra says:
If consciousness does not enter the mother's womb, can name-and-form come to be in the kalala state?
And so on at length.
Although the mind at death may be of three natures, an arhat definitely has no defiled mind.
Although there is a good mind and two indeterminate minds, because they are strong, one does not enter nirvana.
The mind that enters nirvana is only of two kinds of indeterminate natures, namely, the mind of deportment or the mind born of retribution.
If it is said that in the desire realm there is a mind of indifference as retribution that enters nirvana, it is of two kinds of indeterminate natures.
If you say that the mind of entry into nirvana in the desire realm is without the retribution of equanimity, but is only the path of deportment, then there must be no mind apart from feeling.
Why does inferior good not enter nirvana?
Because that good mind has retribution.
Because arhats are disgusted with future retributions and enter nirvana.
If that is so, then the mind of retribution should not enter nirvana.
No, because it has already been distinguished that they are disgusted with the future.
Why are they not disgusted with the present retribution?
Because they know that by relying on the present retribution, all existence is permanently severed.
Relying on the present retribution to realize the fruit of no-more-learning, they know its kindness and are not deeply disgusted with it.

Arhats are deeply disgusted with future births, so when their lives end they avoid the good that is the cause of that, and only the two indeterminate [minds] enter nirvana. Because their power is weak, they accord with the indistinct and weak, and the mind of the severed continuum.
Although the various consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness rely on the material faculties, they have no location, let alone the mental consciousness.

However, when it is said that consciousness ceases in the place where the body ceases, if death is sudden, then both mental consciousness and the body suddenly cease altogether and there is no specific place.
If death is gradual, then when one is born in the human or heavenly realms, consciousness ceases in the feet, navel, or heart, respectively.
That is, when one falls into an evil destiny, it is said that one goes downward, and consciousness finally ceases in the two feet.
If one is born in the human realm, consciousness ceases in the navel.
If one is born in the heavenly realm, consciousness ceases in the heart.
Arhats are said to be unborn, and their final mind also ceases in the heart.
Other masters say:
It ceases in the head.

When one is dying, because the body faculty ceases in the feet, etc., mental consciousness also ceases. When one is dying, the body faculty gradually diminishes until it suddenly ceases altogether in the feet, etc., just as when a little water is placed on a hot stone, it gradually diminishes and disappears until it is completely gone in one place.
There is definitely no homogeneous character that can be the cause for the uninterrupted production of subsequent existence in the destinies.
Only those who die gradually, when they are about to die, have the pain of the final moxa to cut off.
There is no separate thing called moxa, but there are separate places in the body. When the wind and heat are raging and pressing, extreme pain arises and one immediately dies, and it is called moxa.
As a verse says:
In the body there are separate places, touched which will cause death,
Like the touch of the stamens of a blue lotus flower, or dust, etc.
If the conditions of water, fire, and wind do not balance, they combine and mutually oppose each other, either collectively or individually, and their power increases and violently injures the moxa.
Like using a sharp knife to dissect the limbs, from this extreme pain is produced, and one will definitely give up life in an instant.
For this reason it is called cutting off the moxa.
It is not like cutting firewood, which is called cutting. It is called cutting because it is cut off without awareness.

They are fond of speaking words that criticize others, regardless of whether they are true or not, and hurt people's hearts. Because of this, they will experience the suffering of having their intestines severed.
Why is the earth element not the severing of intestines?
Because there is no fourth internal calamity.
The three internal calamities are wind, heat, and phlegm, which increase and give rise to the appropriate [calamities] according to circumstances.
Some say this resembles the three calamities of the external environment.
This severing of intestines does not exist in the heavens.
However, when the heavenly beings are about to die, five kinds of minor signs of decline first appear:
First, the clothes and ornaments lose their pleasing sounds;
Second, the light of their own bodies suddenly becomes dim;
Third, water droplets stick to the body during bathing;
Fourth, the originally restless nature now lingers on one object;
Fifth, the eyes, which were originally still, now move frequently.
These five signs do not necessarily mean death, because they can still be reversed if one encounters excellent wholesome conditions.
There are also five kinds of major signs of decline that appear:
First, the clothes become dusty;
second, the flower garlands wither;
third, sweat appears in the two armpits;
fourth, a foul smell enters the body;
fifth, one does not enjoy one's original seat.
When these five signs appear, one will definitely die. Even if one encounters powerful conditions, it cannot be averted.
The World-Honored One, in this world of sentient beings, establishes three groups in terms of birth, abiding, and passing away.
What are the three groups?
Verse:
The group of right nature, the group of wrong nature, and the indeterminate group, the sages, those who commit the five heinous crimes, and the rest.
Discussion:
First, the group of definite right nature; second, the group of definite wrong nature; third, the group of indeterminate nature.
What is called right nature?
The World-Honored One said:
The complete elimination of greed, the complete elimination of anger, the complete elimination of delusion, and the complete elimination of all afflictions is called right nature.
Why is only elimination called right nature?
Because it is the eternal end of false dharmas.
Moreover, it is good and eternal, and is definitely loved by the wise.
The World Honored One also says:
The noble path is called right nature.
The sutra says:
Because it enters right nature and leaves birth.
What is called wrong nature?
There are three kinds:

First, the nature of going wrong; second, the nature of karma going wrong; third, the nature of views going wrong. They are the body of the five evil destinies and the five uninterrupted karmas, and the five wrong views respectively.
For those in the two concentrations, the dharmas of learning and no-learning, the five uninterrupted karmas are respectively determined to leave the fetters and the hell fruit.
One who accomplishes this is called one who attains this aggregate, and is called a noble one.
One who creates the uninterrupted [karmas] is truly liberated, because they are already liberated from the bonds of afflictions, and is called a noble one.
Noble means self-mastery and freedom from bondage.
Or because they are far from many evils, they are called noble, because they have attained the ultimate liberation.
Or because they are well-directed, they are called noble.
There is no interruption in the middle, so it is called uninterrupted.
Because they like to make this cause, it is called creation.
Those of fixed wholesome and unwholesome natures are called those of fixed nature, because they are able to attain the two [natures] in dependence on two conditions.
